article.title: Causant%C3%ADn_mac_Cin%C3%A1eda
article.paragraph: Infobox royaltyCausantín mac Cináeda Causantín mac Cináeda.jpg 200 18th century depiction of Causantín, son of Kenneth MacAlpin. The depiction is highly anachronistic. [[List of Kings of the Picts|King of the Picts]] 862–877 [[Domnall mac Ailpín|Donald I]] [[Áed mac Cináeda|Áed]] [[Donald II of Scotland|Donald II]], King of the Picts/of Alba [[House of Alpin|Alpin]] [[Kenneth MacAlpin|Kenneth I]], King of the Picts 877 [[Atholl]]? [[Iona]] CausantnorConstantn mac Cineda(inScottish GaelicModern Gaelic,Ciseam mac Choinnich; died 877) was alist of Kings of the Pictsking of the Picts. He is often known asConstantine I, in reference to his place in modern lists ofkings of Scots, though contemporary sources described Causantn only as a Pictish king. A son ofCined mac Ailpn("Kenneth MacAlpin"), he succeeded his uncleDomnall mac Ailpnas Pictish king following the latter's death on 13 April 862. It is likely that Causantn's (Constantine I) reign witnessed increased activity byVikings, based inIreland, inNorthumbriaand in northernGreat BritainBritain. He died fighting one such invasion.
article.heading: Sources
article.paragraph: Very few records of ninth century events in northern Britain survive. The main local source from the period is theChronicle of the Kings of Alba, a list of kings from Cined mac Ailpn (died 858) toCined mac Mal Coluim(died 995). The list survives in thePoppleton Manuscript, a thirteenth-century compilation. Originally simply a list of kings with reign lengths, the other details contained in the Poppleton Manuscript version were added from the tenth century onwards.Woolf,Pictland to Alba, pp. 87–93; Dumville, "Chronicle of the Kings of Alba".In addition to this, later king lists survive.Anderson,Kings and Kingship, reproduces these lists and discusses their origins, further discussed by Broun,Irish origins.The earliestgenealogicalrecords of the descendants of Cined mac Ailpn may date from the end of the tenth century, but their value lies more in their context, and the information they provide about the interests of those for whom they were compiled, than in the unreliable claims they contain.Broun,Irish Identity, pp. 133–164; Woolf,Pictland to Alba, pp. 220–221.The Pictish king-lists originally ended with this Causantn, who was reckoned the seventieth and last king of the Picts.Broun,Irish Identity, p. 168–169; Anderson,Kings and Kingship, p. 78

For narrative history the principal sources are theAnglo-Saxon Chronicleand the Irish annals. WhileScandinaviansagasdescribe events in 9th century Britain, their value as sources of historical narrative, rather than documents of social history, is disputed.Woolf,Pictland to Alba, pp. 277–285; Corrain, "Vikings in Scotland and Ireland"...If the sources for north-eastern Britain, the lands of the kingdom ofNorthumbriaand the former Pictland, are limited and late, those for the areas on theIrish SeaandAtlantic OceanAtlanticcoasts—the modern regions of north-west England and all of northern and western Scotland—are non-existent, andarchaeologyandtoponymyare of primary importance.Woolf,Pictland to Alba, p. 12.
article.heading: Languages and names
article.paragraph: Writing a century before Causantn was born,Bederecorded five languages in Britain.Latin, the common language of the church,Old English languageOld English, the language of the Angles and Saxons,Irish languageIrish, spoken on the western coasts of Britain and in Ireland,British language (Celtic)Brythonic, ancestor of theWelsh language, spoken in large parts of western Britain, andPictish languagePictish, spoken in northern Britain. By the ninth century a sixth language,Old Norse, had arrived with the Vikings.
article.heading: Amlab and mar
article.paragraph: Viking activity in northern Britain appears to have reached a peak during Causantn's reign. Viking armies were led by a small group of men who may have been kinsmen. Among those noted by the Irish annals, theChronicle of the Kings of Albaand theAnglo-Saxon Chroniclearemarvarr—mar in Irish sources—who was active fromKingdom of East AngliaEast Angliato Ireland, Halfdn—Albdann in Irish, Healfdene in Old English— andAmlab ConungAmlabor lfr. As well as these leaders, various others related to them appear in the surviving record.Downham, Smyth, Woolf.

Viking activity in Britain increased in 865 when theGreat Heathen Army, probably a part of the forces which had been active inFrancia, landed in East Anglia.Check Nelson.The following year, having obtained tribute from the East Anglian KingEdmund the MartyrEdmund, the Great Army moved north, seizingYork, chief city of the Northumbrians.Downham, Keynes, Woolf.The Great Army defeated an attack on York by the two rivals for the Northumbrian throne,Osberht of NorthumbriaOsberhtandlla of Northumbrialla, who had put aside their differences in the face of a common enemy. Both would-be kings were killed in the failed assault, probably on 21 March 867. Following this, the leaders of the Great Army are said to have installed oneEcgberht I of NorthumbriaEcgberhtas king of the Northumbrians.Downham, Higham, Keynes, O Corrain, Smyth, Woolf.Their next target wasMerciawhere KingBurgred of MerciaBurgred, aided by his brother-in-law Kingthelred of Wessex, drove them off.Keynes ...

While the kingdoms of East Anglia, Mercia and Northumbria were under attack, other Viking armies were active in the far north. Amlab andAuisle(sl or Augsl), said to be his brother, brought an army to Fortriu and obtained tribute and hostages in 866. Historians disagree as to whether the army returned to Ireland in 866, 867 or even in 869.Downham, O Corrain, Smyth, Woolf, AU 866.1.Late sources of uncertain reliability state that Auisle was killed by Amlab in 867 in a dispute over Amlab's wife, the daughter of Cined. It is unclear whether, if accurate, this woman should be identified as a daughter of Cined mac Ailpn, and thus Causantn's sister, or as a daughter ofCined mac Conaing,king of Brega.Downham, ??, FAA.While Amlab and Auisle were in north Britain, theAnnals of Ulsterrecord thated Findliath,High King of Ireland, took advantage of their absence to destroy thelongphortsalong the northern coasts of Ireland.Byrne? O Corrain? AU 866.4ed Findliath was married to Causantn's sister Mel Muire. She later married ed's successorFlann Sinna. Her death is recorded in 913.Woolf, AU 913.1, Byrne p. 857, poss. same as Amlab's wife.

In 870, Amlab and varr attackedDumbarton Rock, where theRiver Leven, DunbartonshireRiver Levenmeets theRiver Clyde, the chief place of the kingdom ofAlt Clut, south-western neighbour of Pictland. The siege lasted four months before the fortress fell to the Vikings who returned to Ireland with many prisoners, "Angles, Britons and Picts", in 871. Archaeological evidence suggests that Dumbarton Rock was largely abandoned and thatGovanreplaced it as the chief place of the kingdom of Strathclyde, as Alt Clut was later known.AU 870.6, AU 871.2, Woolf, Downham, Smyth.KingArtgal of Alt Clutdid not long survive these events, being killed "at the instigation" of Causantn son of Cined two years later. Artgal's son and successorRun of Alt ClutRunwas married to a sister of Causantn.AU 872.5, Smyth, Woolf.

Amlab disappears from Irish annals after his return to Ireland in 871. According to theChronicle of the Kings of Albahe was killed by Causantn either in 871 or 872 when he returned to Pictland to collect further tribute.Woolf, Downham.His ally varr died in 873.Woolf, Downham, AU 873.3
article.heading: Last days of the Pictish kingdom
article.paragraph: In 875, theChronicleand theAnnals of Ulsteragain report a Viking army in Pictland. A battle, fought nearDollar, ClackmannanshireDollar, was a heavy defeat for the Picts; theAnnals of Ulstersay that "a great slaughter of the Picts resulted". In 877, shortly after building a new church for the Culdees at St Andrews, Causantn was captured and executed (or perhaps killed in battle) after defending against Viking raiders.Raymond Lamont-Brown,St Andrews: City by the Northern Sea(Edinburgh: Berlinn, 2006), 9.Although there is agreement on the time and general manner of his death, it is not clear where this happened. Some believe he was beheaded on a Fife beach, following a battle at Fife Ness, near Crail.William Forbes Skenereads theChronicleas placing Causantn's death at Inverdovat (byNewport-on-Tay), which appears to match theProphecy of Berchn. The account in theChronicle of Melrosenames the place as the "Black Cave," andJohn of Forduncalls it the "Black Den". Causantn was buried onIona.
article.heading: Aftermath
article.paragraph: Causantn's sonDonald II of ScotlandDomnalland his descendants represented the main line of thekings of Albaand laterScotland.
article.heading: Notes
